questions.text: Consent is a good defence in ________.
questions.solution:
Consent is a good defence in Civil negligence 

Difference between civil and criminal negligence

  Civil negligence  Criminal negligence 
Offence   No specific and clear violation of law need to be proved.   Must have specifically violated a particular criminal law. 
Negligence  Simple absence of care and skill.  Gross negligence.  
Consent   Good defence, cannot recover damages.   Not a defence. Can be prosecuted.  
Litigation   Between two parties    Between state and doctor  
Trial by  Civil court    Criminal court  
Evidence     Strong evidence is sufficient     Guilt should be proved beyond reasonable doubt  
Punishment    Liable to pay damages  Imprisonment   

Ethical negligence is violation of code of medical ethics; Consent is not related to this.

questions.text: Conduct money is paid in
questions.solution:
Conduct money is the fee paid to the witness in civil cases at the time of serving the summons, to meet the expenses of attending the court. 

Note: In criminal cases, no fee is paid to the witness at the time of serving the summons but if the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules. As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata" .

questions.text: McNaughten rule is concerned with ______.
questions.solution:
The McNaughten rule is concerned with the criminal responsibility of the insane. In India, the law of criminal responsibility is under Sec 84 I.P.C.

  • McNaughten’s Rule was formed by the Judges of McNaughten’s case, to clarify the common law of insanity in England during 1843. It is similar to IPC 84 which states “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
  • Curren's rule of 1961 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
  • Durham's rule of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect. 

 

Other options - 

Option A: Criminal responsibility for voluntary intoxication - An intoxicated person (voluntary intoxication) is criminally responsible if he had the intention or knowledge of committing a crime (Sec 86 IPC).

Option B: Criminal responsibility for involuntary intoxication - An act done by a person, who is incapable of knowing the nature of the act due to intoxication is not an offence, if the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will (Sec 85 IPC)

Option D: Criminal responsibility of a child - Any act which is done by a child under seven years of age is not an offence (Sec 82 IPC). A child between 7-12 years is presumed to be capable of committing an offence, if he attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion (Sec. 83 IPC). This maturity is presumed in a child unless proved otherwise by the defence.

questions.text: Who can be considered as an expert witness?
questions.solution:
All of the above can be considered as an expert witness.

An expert witness is a person who is skilled in technical or scientific objects and capable of drawing opinions and conclusions from the fact observed by him or by others.  Examples: Doctor, Firearm expert, fingerprinting expert, handwriting expert. (S. 45 I.E.A.)

 

Witnesses: A witness is a person who gives evidence regarding facts. Sec 118 to 134 of I.E.A deal with witnesses

Other types of witnesses: 

  • Common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed by him.  The first-hand knowledge rule refers to the concept that the witness must show that he was capable of perceiving the fact by one of his own senses and that he actually observed this fact. It is applicable to all common witness who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him/her.

A doctor can be both a common and expert witness. Common witness - When he describes the wounds on the body.  Expert witness - when he says that the wounds were antemortem or post-mortem, or they were suicidal, homicidal, or accidental, or gives an opinion regarding the cause of death.

  • A hostile witness is one who has some interest or motive for concealing part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence(Sec 191 IPC). There must be some evidence to prove that the witness has retracted from his earlier statement or is not desirous of disclosing the truth, or has exhibited an element of hostility. If a witness is declared as hostile, he can be cross-examined by the same side lawyer.

Perjury is defined as the offence of wilfully telling an untruth or making a misrepresentation under oath. IPC 193 deals with punishment for false evidence. A person who intentionally gives false evidence or produces fabricated evidence for it to be used in a judicial proceeding shall be punished with imprisonment up to 7 years, and also liable to a fine.

questions.text: Indians are_______
questions.solution:
Average Indian has a Mesaticephalic skull.

The skull of an Indian is Caucasian with a few Negroid characteristics. Because of racial mixing, the Indian skull cannot be correctly differentiated into the broad categories of Dolichocephalic, Mesaticephalic, and Brachycephalic.

Note: This is a controversial question. The use of the cephalic index for determination of race has been discredited and the cephalic index of the entire Indian population cannot be generalized to belong to one category. But the best answer to this question is Mesaticephalic.

Pure Aryans, Aborigines and Negroes are Dolicocephalic with Cephalic index 70–75.

questions.text: A 20-year-old who was found missing for the past three days was later found in a swimming pool nearby. On examination, parts of the faded tattoo were found remaining on his back. Which of the following tests can best reveal the presence of a tattoo in its entirety?
questions.solution:
Infrared photography makes old tattoos readily visible. Also, due to its non-invasive nature and micron-level resolution along with the use of common equipment in forensic laboratories, has placed this technique over others in visualising faded tattoo marks.

A faded tattoo mark can be visualized by:

  • Ultraviolet light
  • Infrared photography
  • Rubbing the part and examining it with a magnifying lens
  • 3% Hydrogen peroxide

In decomposed bodies, the tattoo marks can be visualized by removing the epidermis with a moist cloth. The lymph nodes near a tattoo mark also show a deposit of the pigment.

Other options:

Option A: A magnifying lens can be used but is inferior to infrared photography.

Option C: Although optical coherence tomography can be used to visualise faded tattoos, the increased technical skill required to utilise this technique makes it not very viable.

Option D: Hydrogen peroxide can also be used to visualise faded tattoos but due to its destructive nature it has been replaced by the use of infrared photography. Also, prior knowledge of the existence of a tattoo at the location is required prior to the application of hydrogen peroxide.

questions.text: Nobbing fracture is common in
questions.solution:
Nobbing fracture is common in Battered baby syndrome.

  • In battered baby syndrome or infantile whiplash syndrome violent squeezing of chest from side to side causes fracture of costochondral junctions and also along the posterior angles of the rib.
  • After callus formation which takes around 2 weeks, it gives “string of beads” appearance in paravertebral region on X ray also known as nobbing fractures.

questions.text: In starvation gall bladder is
questions.solution:
In starvation, the gall bladder is distended.

In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the stomach due to absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. So bile gets accumulated in gall bladder and gets distended.

Starvation:

  • Feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30-48 hours.
  • Person can survive for 10-12 days without food and water and for 6-8 weeks without food alone.
  • Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal. 
  • Loss of 70-90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal. 
  • There is reduction in weight and size of all organs except brain.

questions.text: Most cases of drowning in India are
questions.solution:
Most cases of drowning in India are accidental.

Accidental drowning is the most common form seen usually in epileptics, intoxicated individuals, swimmers, fisherman, dock workers etc.

Option A: Homicidal drowning is the rarest form of drowning.

Option B: Suicidal drowning is common in women.

questions.text: The postmortem finding seen in smothering is

choices.text: Abrasion on the inner side of the mouth

questions.solution:
Abrasion on the inner side of mouth is found in smothering.

Smothering is a form of asphyxia which occurs due to closure of external respiratory orifices by means of hands or by blocking of nose or mouth using foreign substances like mud, cloth etc.

Accidental smothering is the most common type.

Postmortem findings in case of smothering:

  • Since there is slow asphyxia, asphyxial signs will be severe.
  • Victim’s face might show lacerations, nail marks and scratches.
  • Bruising and laceration of lips, gums and tongue and oozing of blood from mouth and nose will be seen.
  • Protruded tongue
  • Asphyxial signs are absent in case of sudden death due to reflex cardiac arrest and in case of plastic bag suffocation.

questions.text: Identify the given image
questions.solution:
The given image describes Lilliputian hallucination:

  • In delirious states, visual hallucinations of small animals are common.
  • In alcoholic delirium tremens, lilliputian hallucinations, i.e. hallucinations of small animals and human beings, are reported (person sees figures in reduced size like midgets or dwarfs).
  • Scenic hallucinations are associated with various psychiatric disorders and also temporal lobe epilepsy

questions.text: Identify the type of illusion in the given image?
questions.solution:
The type of illusion in the given image is pareidolic illusions. Pareidolic illusions are those where images are seen from shapes, e.g. seeing human faces in the rocks.

Illusions may be of three types:

  • Completion illusions
  • Affect illusions
  • Pareidolic illusions

Completion illusions are seen in human tendency to complete a familiar and unfinished pattern.

Affect illusions can be understood in context with the prevailing mood state.

questions.text: In dry drowning, death commonly occurs due to

choices.text: Entry of water into the alveoli

questions.solution:
In dry drowning, death occurs due to immediate sustained laryngospasm. 

In dry drowning, water does not enter the lungs, but death results from immediate sustained laryngeal spasm due to inrush of water into the  nasopharynx or larynx. Thick mucus, foam and froth may develop, producing a plug. This is seen in some cases of immersion and is commonly seen in children and adults under the influence of alcohol or sedative hypnotics.

Drowning can also cause hypoxia to vital tissues like brain and heart leading to cardiac dysrhythmias (progressing from tachycardia, bradycardia, pulseless electrical activity, and asystole)

Other types of drowning:

  • Wet/primary/typical drowning: Water enters lungs and death occurs due to cardiac arrest or ventricular fibrillation.
  • Secondary drowning/post immersion syndrome/near drowning: It is a condition where victim of drowning is resuscitated and survives for 24 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sex chromatin is false?

choices.text: 2 Barr bodies are seen in a person with 47XXY genetic makeup
Barr body may be seen in a genetic male
Davidson body seen in neutrophil nucleus
A common site for sex chromatin sampling is tooth pulp

questions.solution:
The number of Barr bodies in someone with 47XXY genetic makeup is 1, not 2. The number of Barr bodies is given by the formula n-1, where n is the number of X chromosomes. 

Barr body is a small planoconvex mass, lying near the nuclear membrane. It represents the inactivated X chromosome. Barr bodies are seen in 0-4% of genetic males (46XY) and 20-80% of genetic females (46XX).

Sites for sampling for sex chromatin include

  • Buccal mucosa
  • Tooth pulp 
  • Hair bulb

Davidson body is a drumstick-shaped mass of chromatin hanging down from neutrophil nuclei. It is seen only in females (0-6%).

questions.text: In a peculiar case of robbery, the forensic team finds that no finger prints were left behind despite the footage showing that the thief did not wear any gloves. Which of the following medical conditions could he be suffering from?
questions.solution:
A person suffering from dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis (DPR) has a lack of fingerprint patterns, and hence will not leave fingerprint marks.

There are two closely related autosomal dominant ectodermal dysplasia syndromes causing complete absence of fingerprints. They are Naegeli–Franceschetti–Jadassohn syndrome (NFJS) and dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis (DPR).

A permanent damage of fingerprints also occurs in patients with leprosy, electrical injury, and irradiation.

questions.text: A convict who was earlier granted a death sentence was then later commuted to life imprisonment. What IPC section does this come under?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 54 deals with the commutation of a death sentence. Commutation denotes the substitution of one form of punishment for a lighter form. For example, a death sentence commuted to life imprisonment.

Sections 53 to 75 of the IPC deal with punishments. 

Option A: IPC 51 denotes the section on oath. It includes a solemn affirmation sub­stituted by law for an oath, and any declaration required or authorized by law to be made before a public servant or to be used for the purpose of proof, whether in a Court of Justice or not. 

Option B: IPC 53 denotes the section on punishments. The punishments provided are death, life imprisonment, imprisonment for a certain time, forfeiture of property, and lastly fine.

Option D: IPC 55 denotes the commutation of a sentence of life imprisonment.

questions.text: A newly married woman was found dead in her house. On inquiry, it was informed by the neighbours that the couple used to fight a lot regarding dowry. Which section deals with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Dowry Death is defined under section 80 of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 2023 (IPC 304B).

  • If a husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage, they shall be deemed to have caused her death.
  • The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: You are declaring a patient brain dead by using Harvard criteria. All of the following parameters are checked for, except:
questions.solution:
Isoelectric EEG is included in Harvard criteria for brain death and not ECG.

Harvard criteria for brain death include:

  • Unreceptivity and unresponsiveness
  • No movements
  • Apnoea
  • Absence of elicitable reflexes
  • Isoelectric EEG (confirmatory)

All these tests should be recorded. If there is no change after 24 hours, then the patient is declared brain dead.

Philadelphia protocol, Minnesota criteria are other criteria used to diagnose brain death.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about cadaveric rigidity in contrast to cadaveric spasm?
  1. It is due to the depletion of ATP
  2. Muscles respond to electrical stimuli
  3. It happens instantaneously after death
  4. It is an antemortem phenomenon
  5. It indicates time since death
questions.solution:
Cadaveric rigidity is also known as rigor mortis. It is due to the depletion of ATP and indicates time since death. Muscle stiffening is not marked and can be overcome by moderate force. The rigor starts occurring 1-2 hours after death (postmortem nature) and muscles do not respond to electrical stimuli.

Cadaveric spasm / instantaneous rigor/ cataleptic rigidity/ death clutch is a phenomenon where a group of muscles in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death until molecular death occurs.

Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem phenomenon and occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like:

  • In cases of excitement, fear, severe pain
  • Exhaustion at the time of death
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Injury to the nervous system
  • Drowning
  • Strychnine poisoning

Examples:

  • In case of drowning, weeds and grass caught in hand during struggle remain firmly grasped even after death. This indicates that the person was alive when entering the water
  • In case of suicides, weapons remain firmly grasped in the hand

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

Trait Cadaveric rigidity Cadaveric spasm
Production Freezing and exposure to a temperature above 650C will produce rigor Cannot be produced by any method after death
Mechanism Reduction of ATP Not clear
Predisposing factors Nil Sudden death, excitement, fear, etc
Time of onset 1 – 2 hours after death Instantaneous
Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline
Medicolegal importance Indicates the time of death Indicates manner of death

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ectopic contusions?

choices.text: Bruising on the neck may indicate a jaw fracture
Bruising at the nape of the neck indicates fracture of the posterior cranial fossa
A black eye may be from fracture of the anterior cranial fossa
Bruising behind the ear indicates fracture of the middle cranial fossa

questions.solution:
Bruising at the nape of the neck does not indicate a fracture of the posterior cranial fossa.

Ectopic bruises are also called migratory/percolated bruising. They are found at a different location than the actual site of injury. They are caused by the percolation of blood in the subcutaneous tissue from one site to another.

Examples are:

  • Black eye - due to actual trauma to the eye, or maybe an ectopic bruise. It may be from trauma to the forehead or from a fracture of the anterior cranial fossa.

The image below shows a black eye.

  • Battle sign - bruising seen over the mastoid process. It is from a fracture of the middle cranial fossa. 

The image given below shows battle sign.

  • Bruising on the neck may indicate a jaw fracture.

questions.text: An abrasion involves which of the following layers of the skin?
questions.solution:
An abrasion is the most superficial of injuries and is one that does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.

Thus the pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. The dermal papillae are corrugated in nature. Therefore, many abrasions enter the dermis, and bleeding commonly occurs.

Abrasions are commonly known as grazes or scratches.

questions.text: Fracture through the line shown in the image is called as?
questions.solution:
The line shown in the given image corresponds closely to the location of a hinge fracture of the base of the skull, also called a motorcyclist's fracture.

It is a basal linear fracture that passes across the floor of the middle cranial fossa, often following the petrous temporal or greater wing of the sphenoid bone into the pituitary fossa. This frequently continues symmetrically across the other middle fossa separating the base of the skull into two halves, usually being caused by a heavy blow on the side of the head and is associated with injuries to the brainstem (pontomedullary tears).

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding contrecoup injuries?

choices.text: Fracture of the skull may not occur, even in the presence of severe coup and contrecoup injuries
A fall on the frontal region will produce an occipital contrecoup
A fall on the temporal region will produce a contrecoup in the ipsilateral lobe
The most common site for contrecoup injury is frontal and temporal lobes

questions.solution:
A fall on the frontal region will not produce occipital contrecoup injuries. This is due to the relatively smooth internal surface of the posterior cranial fossa.

Coup injury is damage that occurs on the same side of the direct trauma. Contrecoup injuries are present opposite to the site of trauma and is due to shear strain.

Fracture of the skull may not occur, even in the presence of severe coup and contrecoup injuries (option A). The skull's anterior and middle cranial fossae have sharp edges. This makes the temporal and frontal lobes highly prone to contrecoup injuries (option D). 

A fall on the temporal region can produce a contrecoup injury on the ipsilateral lobe due to the presence of the falx cerebri (option C).
During the impact, the ipsilateral lobe moves in the opposite direction striking the falx cerebri, resulting in contrecoup injury on the same lobe (as the impact) but opposite to the site of initial trauma.

questions.text: An elderly woman was found dead during winter in her wardrobe. On house inspection, the heater was found to be broken. She was also identified to be a known case of hypothyroidism. Which of the following most likely explains her scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely explanation for the given scenario is terminal burrowing behaviour or hide and die syndrome. 

An elderly lady with hypothyroidism is more likely to develop hypothermia. About 20% of hypothermia cases are associated with terminal burrowing behaviour.

In some cases the bodies were found in strange situations, i.e. lying under a bed, behind a wardrobe, or on a shelf, etc. indicating that the final positions were a kind of self-protective burrowing-like behaviour.

questions.text: Which of the following features of electrical injury will develop if the contact with the electrocuting surface is poorly established?
questions.solution:
When the contact with the electrocuting surface is not firm, the skin lesion that develops is called a spark lesion.

When the contact is less firm, an air gap (albeit narrow) exists between skin and conductor the current jumps the gap as a spark. This causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area. On cooling, the keratin fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface.

Various skin lesions in electrical injury:

  • When the skin has been in firm contact with an electrical conductor, this may split the layers of the epidermis or the epidermal-dermal junction and produce a raised blister called Joule burns.
  • In high-voltage burns, such as those sustained from high-tension grid transmission cables, where the voltage is in the multi-kilovolt range, sparking may occur over many centimeters. This can cause multiple spark lesions giving rise to a ‘crocodile-skin’ effect.
  • The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci called as 'bone pearls' or 'wax drippings'.

questions.text: A rifled weapon produces damage mainly by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Rifled weapons produce most of their damage by cavitation effect.

Two different mechanisms of injury can be distinguished when a projectile penetrates a dense medium such as tissue:

  • Crush-mechanism and Permanent Tract - Tissue located in line with the trajectory is crushed by excessive pressures buildup directly in front of the tip of the moving projectile. The tissue is completely disintegrated, resulting morphologically in the permanent tract. This is the main mechanism of damage in a shotgun.

  • Stretch-mechanism and Temporary Cavity - Tissue located at the side of the trajectory is temporarily accelerated radially. This radial displacement of tissue creates a fusiform or conical cavity. Tissue elasticity causes the cavity to collapse immediately, hence the name temporary cavity. This is the main mechanism of damage in a rifled gun.

Note : A shotgun cannot cause cavitation effect as the pellets never achieve sufficient velocity to be able to accelerate the surrounding tissue.

questions.text: While examining a man who is accused of rape, you find the presence of smegma on his corona glandis. Which of the following can be inferred from this finding?

choices.text: The person has engaged in sexual act recently
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 24 hours
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 48 hours
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 1 week

questions.solution:
The presence of smegma on the corona glandis indicates that the person has not engaged in a sexual act in the last 24 hours.

Smegma requires about 24 hours to collect. It gets removed by bathing or washing or intercourse. The absence indicates sexual activity might have been performed in the last 24 hours as it gets rubbed off during intercourse. The presence of smegma absolutely negates the possibility of complete penetration.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the doctor because his family found him dressed as a woman. He says that he derives sexual pleasure from this act. However, he has no wish to undergo sex-change surgery. What is this type of perversion called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetishistic transvestism.

It is a paraphilia characterized by recurrent sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges, or behavior involving the wearing of clothes of the opposite sex and appearing as a member of the opposite sex. It is also called transvestic fetishism. It is usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes.

Fetishistic transvestism is a paraphilia whereas transvestism is a gender identity disorder. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality in fetishistic transvestism.

Option A: Transsexualism refers to an obsessional desire to become a member of the opposite sex and seek surgery for anatomical alterations. 

Option C: Frotteurism refers to a person who obtains sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, or thighs, in public places). It is punishable under Sec 292 BNS (Section 290 IPC), with a fine of up to 1000 rupees.

Option D: Gender dysphoria is a term that describes a sense of unease that a person has due to a mismatch between their biological sex and their gender identity. This sense of unease or dissatisfaction can lead to depression and anxiety and can have a harmful impact on daily life.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: A woman presented with vomiting and diarrhea followed by chest pain and palpitations. Later, it was revealed that due to her unfaithfulness, her husband poisoned her with foxglove. Which of the following is the most specific treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Digitalis purpurea is also known as foxglove. The most specific antidote for its poisoning is digoxin-immune Fab fragments. 

Digitalis is a cardioactive steroid that acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium (Na+-K+) ATPase pump. Acute toxicity closely resembles that caused by digoxin and includes early GI symptoms, followed by cardiac dysrhythmias.

Digoxin immune Fab fragments should be administered to those with serum potassium >5 mEq/L in patients with acute toxicity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to the ER with severe dehydration and weakness. History was suggestive of multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and non-bilious vomiting since morning. His breath reeked of garlic odor. ECG showed QT prolongation.  Which of the following samples must be collected for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of acute arsenic poisoning. For a definitive diagnosis, the arsenic levels are measured in 24-hour urine samples.

If the baseline urinary level is within normal limits and arsenic intoxication is still suspected, hair and nail clippings should be harvested for laboratory analysis. Due to the rapid distribution of arsenic in tissues, blood arsenic levels are unreliable.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of anemia, foot drop, and behavioral changes. On examination, there are bluish-gray lines on the gum. The image shows the radiograph of the knee of the patient. Deposition of which substance is responsible for this finding in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is suggestive of lead lines seen in lead toxicity which are due to the deposition of calcium at the growth plates.

The radiodensity of the lead line is due to persistent mineralized metaphyseal cartilage and not to a primary osseous change or lead itself. It is the result of a lead-induced inability of cartilage-resorbing cells to degrade the mineralized matrix. This impairs the resorption of metaphyseal cartilage.

questions.text: The color of urine in a 25-year-old girl who ingested some unknown poison is given in the image below. Which of the following is likely to have been ingested by her?
questions.solution:
The given image shows olive green colored urine which is known as carboluria. It is seen after ingestion of carbolic acid.

In carbolic acid poisoning, if the patient survives for 48 hrs, there will be carboluria followed by anuria. Carboluria is due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrecatechol on exposure to air.

questions.text: You are suspecting organophosphorus poisoning in a farmer who presented with chronic fatigue and urinary incontinence. What would be the most accurate investigation to assess potential toxicity?

choices.text: Urinary levels of organophosphorus compound metabolites

questions.solution:
RBC cholinesterase enzyme activity is the most accurate indicator to assess potential organophosphorus (OP) toxicity. It is an indicator of synaptic cholinesterase inhibition.

However, plasma butyrylcholinesterase is easier to assay and more easily available. Hence, it is more commonly used.

Measurement of parent compound in blood and metabolites urine are rarely carried out in a clinical setting.

Note: The correlation between cholinesterase activity, clinical symptoms, and atropine dose is inconsistent. Hence, treatment should be guided predominately by clinical symptoms.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of mortality in patients with organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution: The most common cause of death in organophosphate poisoning is respiratory failure. It usually occurs within 24 hours in untreated patients, secondary to paralysis of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding opioid intoxication?

choices.text: Hallucination results from stimulation of kappa receptors
Bronchospasm is due to histamine release
Opioid-induce acute lung injury is a rare complication
Opioid intoxication can be ruled out in absence of miosis

questions.solution:
Miosis is not universally present in intoxication from every opioid. Its absence cannot be used to rule out opioid intoxication. Normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity.

  • Histamine release resulting in localized urticaria
  • Ileus secondary to decreased GI motility
  • Urinary retention secondary to increased vesical sphincter tone
  • Respiratory depression, bronchospasm (histamine release), acute lung injury (rare complication)

questions.text: The method shown in the image below is called chasing the dragon. Which drug is taken through this route?
questions.solution:
Chasing the dragon is a method used to take heroin.

In this, users inhale a thick, white pyrolysate that is generated by heating heroin base on aluminum foil using a hand-held flame. This means of administration produces heroin concentrations similar to those observed following IV administration.

Other methods used to take drugs are:

  • Mainlining - Intravenous injection
  • Insufflation - Snorting
  • Skin popping - Subcutaneous injection

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered as unnatural sexual offences in India?
  1. Sodomy
  2. Bestiality
  3. Tribadism
  4. Incest
  5. Buccal coitus
questions.solution:
Bestiality is an act of using a lower animal for sexual gratification. It is an unnatural sexual offence and is punishable in India.

Sexual offences may be described as natural or unnatural offences:

  • Natural sexual offences: Sexual offences committed in order of nature. Eg: rape.
  • Unnatural sexual offences: Sexual offences committed against the order of nature. Eg: bestiality.

Incest is sexual intercourse between man and woman who are related by blood or a certain degree of blood relationship. In India, incest per se is not a crime unless it attracts provisions of rape. It comes under the category of natural sexual offenses if the act is non-consensual.

Sodomy/buggery is consensual anal intercourse between man and man or man and woman. It has been decriminalized now.

Tribadism/lesbianism means female homosexuality. It has been decriminalised now though it was not punishable previously.

Buccal coitus is not a punishable offence, unless it is performed by force or in public.

In a landmark judgment passed on 6th September 2018, the Supreme Court of India scrapped the provisions of Section 377 except the provisions of bestiality which is cruelty against animals.

questions.text: A 25-year-old unmarried woman discovers that she is pregnant. She wishes to undergo an abortion as it was unplanned. Within what period of gestation is this procedure permissible under MTP Amendment Bill, 2021 for this patient?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) for contraceptive failure is permissible up to 20 weeks. This bill was passed by Rajya Sabha on 17th March 2021.

Features of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest, and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors), etc.
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and of two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks of gestation.
  • Upper gestation limit not to apply in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorized in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptives has been extended to women and their partners.

 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.
